_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

Albemarle Pasadena Risk Management Plan - 2019 Resubmission



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



The Albemarle Pasadena facility is committed to operating and maintaining all of chemical processes in a safe and responsible manner so as to protect employees, the community, and the environment.  As a corporation, Albemarle has committed to following the American Chemistry Council's Responsible Care® program, including the Process Safety Code.  Albemarle Corporation's 2018 Health, Safety, Security and Environmental Policy states, in part:



"We are deeply committed to the well-being of all affected by our activities. Our goal is to maintain an incident-free, secure and healthy workspace for all. As a company and as individuals, we will take personal responsibility for safety and are committed to ensuring that we cause no harm to ourselves, our co-workers or the communities in which we operate. Conducting business in a safe, secure and environmentally responsible manner is our ethical responsibility and we will comply with all applicable legal requirements and company policies and procedures. We will be empowered to elevate issues to the appropriate level to ensure proper focus and resources are provided in the event we anticipate or must respond to any issue. If necessary, we will discontinue operations in order to take corrective actions and improve conditions before they lead to incidents, and no one will undertake any task unless it can be done in a safe and environmentally responsible manner. We adhere to the principles and expectations of Responsible Care® in our daily operations. [...] We will consider product safety and environmental impact issues of our products throughout the entire life cycle, including inception, design, development, manufacture, storage, transportation, distribution, marketing, use and disposal. We will be responsive to the concerns of our stakeholders and actively seek participatio

n by them in our programs. We will continually search for innovative and sustainable ways to develop solutions that meet environmental and societal needs today and for generations to come."



The Albemarle Pasadena facility has a robust commitment to emergency response, coordinating site-wide emergency response teams with our site partners, Houston Ship Channel industry neighbors, and local authorities.



Facility and Regulated Substances



The Albemarle Pasadena plant produces a variety of organic industrial chemicals that are sold and transported around the world.  The primary product group at the plant is a family of chemicals known as organometallics.  The primary use of these chemicals is as a catalyst in the plastics and other industries.  Some of the organometallics are also used on-site in the production of other specialty organic chemicals, including industrial intermediates, agricultural chemicals, and curatives.  Albemarle also handles many of the utility services for the complex, including steam production, potable water, thermal transfer fluids, and compressed air.  Albemarle Pasadena shares its site with partner companies.



Per ?68.130, there are six chemicals regulated under the EPA Risk Management Program that are present above the threshold quantity at the Albemarle Pasadena site.  Listed toxic chemicals are chlorine and methyl chloride.  Listed flammable chemicals are 1-butene, ethyl chloride, 2-methylpropene (isobutene), and isopentane.  Anhydrous hydrogen chloride, ethylene, and hydrogen are used on the plant site from pipeline supplies, though these chemicals are not stored or present on site above the threshold quantities.



Chlorine is used onsite for water treatment purposes and has a maximum storage capacity of 8,000-lb.  



Methyl chloride, ethyl chloride, 1-butene, and 2-methylpropene, are each used as reactants in the production of different organometallics.  When methyl chloride is used and stored onsite, the capacity is under 200

,000-lb.  When ethyl chloride is used and stored onsite, the maximum storage capacity is 275,000-lb.  Typical ethyl chloride inventory is about half that due to mixing with another chemical.  Maximum storage capacity of 1-butene is 1,200,000-lb, although typical inventory is much less.  Storage capacity for 2-methylpropene is 200,000-lb.

Isopentane is used as a carrier solvent in one of the organometallic production units, and also as a blending solvent when packaging other organometallic products for shipment.  Total plant inventory of isopentane can be up to 400,000-lb, though the maximum storage capacity in any one area is 200,000-lb.



Regardless of regulatory listing or quantity, Albemarle Pasadena manages all site processes and equipment as if they were covered by the OSHA PSM or EPA RMP standards.  Our release prevention plan and contingency planning programs are tools that we use to manage the potential hazards posed by these chemicals to our employees, the public, and the environment.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program



Albemarle Corporation has always believed in taking a structured, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of chemicals.  The most significant management system in place is the Process Safety Management Program, which is designed to comply with and exceed the requirements set forth by OSHA in 29 CFR 1910.119.  The site also aligns its process safety systems with the Risk-Based Process Safety program as promoted by the Center for Chemical Process Safety (CCPS).  The site has a dedicated process safety manager and is staffed with qualified, safety-trained engineering leadership.  Operations and maintenance personnel are also trained and qualified for their job tasks.  Employees are empowered and encouraged to identify anything out of the ordinary and take corrective action. 

 

All processes (especially those covered by the RMP and PSM standards) are routinely evaluated in a formal process hazard analysis and rea

ctive hazards evaluation, which is at the heart of the release prevention program.  Process safety information for all the processes is well-understood and readily available.  Information from these feeds into the engineering and administrative controls strategy for each production unit.



Processes are operated and controlled with a computer-based distributive control system that is programmed to alert operators of abnormal conditions and take corrective action when safety limits are threatened.  Independent safety instrumented systems are also implemented for certain process units with higher hazard potential.



Safety and reliability are incorporated into the design and construction of the process equipment, following industry standard practices such as those from the American Petroleum Institute, American Society of Mechanical Engineers, International Society of Automation, National Fire Protection Association, and the Chlorine Institute.  Albemarle has also developed a number of internal engineering standards that meet or exceed these standards, especially for materials in which Albemarle has extensive experience and expertise, like organometallics. 



The Albemarle Pasadena site has implemented an aggressive mechanical integrity and inspection program to identify and correct potential problems before they occur.  Processes are routinely inspected for hazards, and corrective actions are implemented in accordance with generally accepted good engineering practices.



Other aspects of the site programs include a continuous learning and improvement element.  The site aims to report and investigate all incidents, especially minor releases, upsets, and deviations that would not be included in the five-year accident history.  The site conducts routine internal audits of management and operating systems.  All changes to the site's processes and technology are proposed, evaluated, and approved through a dedicated Management of Change program.



Occupational safety

programs such as permit-to-work, lock-out/tag-out, and hot work permitting are also key elements of the prevention program.  The site has a dedicated safety department that also supports programs such as behavior-based safety and job observation / feedback to encourage safe operation and behaviors from both employees and contractors.  Contractors are evaluated routinely for their safety, quality, and adherence to Albemarle requirements.  



Chemical-specific Prevention Steps



The site has implemented the following chemical-specific prevention steps:



Chlorine:

- Area monitors are installed near the treatment station to alert operators of any release.

- Only two of four containers are connected to the process at any one time.

- Chlorine is stored away from other major hazard chemical processes.



Methyl Chloride:

- Methyl chloride is inventoried only when it is to be used in the production process, limiting the time at risk.

- Area detectors are installed at the methyl chloride unloading station and in the process area to alert operators of any release.

- The storage vessel and reactor areas are equipped with a deluge system.



Ethyl Chloride:

- Ethyl chloride is mixed and stored with another chemical.

- The storage vessel is equipped with a deluge system and surrounded by a dike and firewalls.

- The storage vessel is insulated to minimize fire exposure.

- The reactor area is equipped with a deluge system



1-Butene:

- The storage vessels are equipped with a deluge system.

- Area detectors are installed at the unloading, storage, and transfer areas to alert operators of any release and automatically shut down operations.



2-Methylpropene:

- The storage vessel is equipped with a deluge system.

- Area detectors are installed at the unloading, storage, and transfer areas to alert operators of any release and automatically shut down operations.



Isopentane:

- The process vessels are equipped with deluge systems or other fire-fighting equipment.

- Process vessels are insulated to minimize fire exposure

- The vessels are located within diked or firewalled areas.

- When isopentane is not being used, it is de-inventoried from the process area.



Five-Year Accident History



The Albemarle Pasadena plant maintains an active incident, investigation, and corrective action database.  A search of our incident database confirmed that there have been no accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, significant property damage onsite, or any offsite consequences per 40 CFR ?68.42 during this five-year period from June 2014 to June 2019.



Emergency Response Program



The Albemarle Pasadena plant maintains a contingency plan that consolidates all federal, state and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  The plant program provides the essential planning and training to effectively protect workers, emergency responders, the public and the environment during an emergency.  Our emergency response plan is coordinated with that of the community, the Southeast Regional LEPC, the Channel Industries Mutual Aid Association (CIMA) and industrial partners who share our fence line.  This shared fence line defines our chemical complex.  Albemarle participates in the eNotify program for public notification of incidents and activities at the site.



The site emergency response team (ERT) is composed of members from all companies operating on the complex.  The ERT consist of four sections that include the fire brigade, the haz-mat team, the rescue team and the emergency medical team.  All team members are trained to the hazardous materials technician level, which allows them to not only respond to fires, but also spills of hazardous material.  To assure that the ERT is ready for any complex emergency, frequent drills are held with our industrial neighbors on the complex.  In addition, the ERT also participates in the local mutual aid (CIMA) drills.  Drills are also used t

o evaluate the ability of complex personnel to understand and operate under the emergency plan.  In addition to our emergency personnel, our emergency response has a fully equipped ambulance, two fire trucks, a rescue vehicle and a haz-mat truck.  In addition to complex emergencies, these vehicles are also available to the Channel Industries Mutual Aid Association for off-plant responses.



Albemarle has the responsibility for maintaining the mobile emergency response equipment and for training of the members of the ERT.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Continuous improvement of safety performance is part of the Albemarle Pasadena's operating philosophy.  This is handled through the PHA program, hazard recognition, and other efforts.  Some current efforts include:

- Expanded installation of safety instrumented systems

- Expanded installation of area monitors in process areas

- An improved electronic management of change system
